title: We're scheduled for debtor's exam tomorrow, but the creditor didn't ask for any documents at time of service. What do we bring?
question: They sent another letter saying that they'll be wanting bank statements, but this wasn't "served" in any official manner, just mailed to us. They also dropped some papers where my husband sometimes works, but he wasn't there, so they just laid the envelope down and left. The business tossed it out. Will we be held in contempt if we don't have everything they ask for?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Motions,Sued for debt,Subpoena,Default judgment
answers:
At judgment debtor exam is not a proceeding at which the court will order payment of anything. The creditor can just ask you questions.

As far as bringing documents, you do not need to bring anything unless you are personally served with a subpoena. "Substituted service", which is allowed for service of a Summons and Complaint, does not work for service of a subpoena.

If you show up, and answer questions, the clerk will let you go home after the examination. The questio0ning is usually done in somewhere outside the courtroom, and no judge is present. You will be sworn by the clerk, and sent to a conference room, an empty jury room, the cafeteria or the hallway, wherever the creditor wants to ask the questions. The last question will be, "How do you intend to pay this?" You do not need to answer such a question. You need to tell the creditor where you work, where your bank account is located, and similar questions, if asked. If you do not know your bank account number by heart, you do not need to say anything that you do not know. The creditor can schedule another exam in 4 months, but will need to pay an additional fee to the court.

If during the exam, the creditor insults you or harasses you, go back to the courtroom and tell the bailiff or clerk.
consult with a local lawyer to review your documents. Generally an OEX is served and then an attachment requesting various documents is attache to the OEX which is personally served on you.

The Order to Appear for Examination has a box that can be checked to bring documents. If this box was not checked, then you don't need to bring any documents. They can only ask questions of you under oath. However, if this default judgment is not set aside, they can request another one of these examinations in 121 days, so they can simply do this again in four months, next time with the correct box checked. I should also note that each time they spend costs on this, that is added to the judgment. If the judgment provided for attorney's fees, they can also add attorney's fees for each hearing. Thus, it is up to you if you want to bring the documents and if you have money and are unemployed, they will probably not want to expend any more time and money on this case. The court will not order you to pay anything at the examination.
